questions.text: A 1-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress. A chest X-ray is performed and is given below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A term neonate presents with failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. Imaging shows a narrow distal bowel segment with proximal colonic dilatation. The Barium Enema image of the neonate is given below. What is the most likely condition affecting this neonate?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Hirschsprung-disease
  • ↳ Toxic megacolon | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. Radiologic studies reveal skip lesions in the ileum and cecum with a cobblestone appearance and deep ulcers. Which of the following radiologic signs is most consistent with this patient's diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Crohn’s Disease

Ulcerative Colitis
  • Skip lesions; ileum and caecum involved; rectum relatively spared.
  • Transmural; leads to ulceration, fissures, abscesses.
  • Bowel wall may be affected asymmetrically with sacculations.
  • Continuous colonic involvement; rectal in 95% of cases.
  • Mucosal and submucosal; less severe.
  • Fissure and abscess are not common.
  • Circumferential bowel wall symmetry is usually maintained.

1. Fluoroscopy (Barium Studies)

  • Mucosal abnormalities: Thickened, nodular folds and a "cobblestone" pattern due to a combination of longitudinal and transverse ulcers.
  • Aphthous ulcers: Appear as areas of barium collection within the swollen mucosa.
  • Shows deep ulcers, fistulae (e.g., enteroenteric, enterocolonic), and sinus tracts.
  • Chronic disease features: Strictures, stenosis, and wall sacculations.
  • String sign of Kantor: A beaded string-like appearance due to multifocal bowel narrowing from strictures.

2. Ultrasonography

  • Concentric mural thickening of the bowel wall.
  • Hyperemia within the inflamed segments.
  • Increased echogenicity of surrounding fat.

3. CT and MRI Enterography

  • Asymmetric Mural thickening
  • Ulcerations: Seen as air or contrast extending into the bowel wall.
  • Strictures
  • Mesenteric changes:
    • Comb sign: Engorgement of the vasa recta.
    • Mesenteric fat stranding, edema, and reactive adenopathy.
  • MRI-specific findings:
    • T2 hyperintense signal: Indicates mural edema, best seen with fat-saturated sequences.
    • Diffusion restriction: Suggestive of active inflammation.
    • Active inflammation shows hyperenhancement in arterial and post-contrast phases.

1. Radiographs

  • Bowel perforation and toxic megacolon: Radiographs (upright and supine) help screen for these conditions.
    • Toxic megacolon: Detected by colonic distension >6 cm, typically in the transverse colon.

Fig. Toxic megacolon in Ulcerative colitis

 
  • Other findings: Air-fluid levels, loss of colonic haustrations, mucosal islands, and absence of formed stool.
 

2. Fluoroscopy (Barium Enema)

  • Mucosal abnormalities: Granular and stippled mucosa, with superficial erosions and ulcers.
    • Collar button ulcers: Deeper ulcers extending into the submucosa. (Option B ruled out)
    • Pseudopolyps
  • Chronic disease features:
    • Lead pipe colon: Luminal narrowing and loss of haustrations in the colon. (Option A & C ruled out)
    • Patulous ileocecal valve (IC valve): With granular terminal ileum, indicative of backwash ileitis.

3. CT and MRI Enterography

  • Active phase:
    • Mural hyperenhancement:
    • Concentric mural thickening with stratification.
    • Submucosal edema: Seen as T2 hyperintensity on MRI.
    • Pseudopolyps
  • Chronic phase:
    • Lead pipe colon: Concentric mural thickening with luminal narrowing and loss of haustrations.
    • Submucosal fat deposition
    • Presacral space widening due to perirectal fat.
    • Post Inflammatory pseudopolyps

Comb Sign in active Crohn’s disease

Leadpipe appearance in Ulcerative colitis

String sign of Kantor and rectovaginal fistula

Inflammatory Pseudopolyps

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chronic abdominal pain, fever, and unintentional weight loss over the past month. He reports altered bowel habits and has a history of exposure to individuals with tuberculosis. A small bowel follow-through imaging is provided below. Based on the clinical presentation and the attached imaging, which of the following features is not typically seen in the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Spasm and edema at the ileocecal valve

options.label: B
options.text: Uniform thickening of the entire colon

options.label: D
options.text: Stierlin Sign with rapid barium emptying

questions.correct_answer: B. Uniform thickening of the entire colon
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ David Sutton Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, Volume 1, 8th edition, Page 2254- 2258
  • ↳ Ileocecal tuberculosis | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting. On examination, her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are decreased. A radiograph abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is not a feature of the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant

questions.correct_answer: B. Maintains a colonic haustral pattern
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sigmoid volvulus vs cecal volvulus | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org
  • ↳ Sigmoid Volvulus Imaging
  • ↳ Cecal Volvulus Imaging and Diagnosis: Practice Essentials, Radiography, Computed Tomography

Sigmoid Volvulus

Caecal Volvulus
  • Sigmoid volvulus arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant. (Option A ruled out)
  • It extends towards the right upper quadrant.
  • It has an ahaustral appearance (lack of haustra).
  • Causes obstruction of the distal large bowel, leading to dilation of the ascending, transverse, and descending colon.
  • A few gas-fluid levels may be seen.
  • Coffee-Bean Sign: The condition is characterized by a distended sigmoid loop with an inverted U shape, known as the coffee-bean sign (or kidney bean sign). (Option D ruled out)
  • Whirlpool Sign: The whirl, or whirlpool sign is observed when the bowel rotates around its mesentery, resulting in whirls of the mesenteric vessels. (Option C ruled out)
  • The torsion is located in the ascending colon above the ileocecal valve.
  • Caecal volvulus arises in the right lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the epigastrium or left upper quadrant.
  • The colonic haustral pattern is maintained.
  • The distal colon is usually collapsed, and the small bowel is distended.
  • One gas-fluid level may be seen.
  • Definitive Sign: Upward displacement of the appendix and obstruction of the large bowel is a definitive sign of cecal volvulus.
  • May show a U-shaped distended bowel segment and signs of ischemia, including mural thickening, infiltration of the mesenteric fat, and pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • Whirlpool Sign: A whirl sign may be apparent due to tight torsion of the mesentery from a twist between the afferent and efferent loops.
  • Coffee Bean Appearance: A "coffee bean" appearance may be seen in a loop of transverse colon.
  • Bird's Beak Sign: Abrupt cut-off with “bird's beak” tapering at the distal cecum is characteristic.
  • Central appendix sign: Abnormal appendix position near midline.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with a known history of lymphoma is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of severe abdominal pain and intermittent vomiting. Her parents report that she has recently passed currant jelly stools. On physical examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted in the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound is given below. Based on the clinical presentation and the ultrasound findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and a distended abdomen. On examination, his bowel sounds are diminished. An abdominal radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on the given findings?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ String of pearls sign (gastrointestinal) | Radiology Reference Article

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with colicky abdominal pain, distension, vomiting, and absolute constipation for the past 48 hours. He has a history of prior abdominal surgery. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. An abdominal X-ray is obtained and shows the following features. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and radiographic findings?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Small Bowel

Large Bowel

Number of loops

Many loops visible

Few loops visible

Position of loops

Central abdomen

Peripheral (framing the small bowel)

Wall/Mucosal pattern

Valvulae conniventes (complete circular folds)

Haustra (incomplete bands)

Diameter

>3 cm

>6 cm (Caecum >9 cm)

Gas Pattern

Multiple air-fluid levels, "string of beads"

Distended colon, air-fluid levels

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. An abdominal X-ray is performed and is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia (Option A)

"Single bubble" sign

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.


 

Duodenal Atresia

(Option B)

"Double bubble" sign

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

Jejunal Atresia

(Option C)

"Triple bubble" sign

Three distended loops of bowel (stomach, duodenum, proximal jejunum) with no distal gas.

Ileal Atresia

(Option D)

Multiple air-fluid levels

Dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels and no gas in the large intestine, more distal than jejunal atresia.

questions.text: Match the following: Barium swallow a) 2.Barium meal b) 3.Barium follow through c) 4.Barium enema d)
questions.explanation:
Barium Studies

Barium swallow

  • Test of the pharynx, esophagus, and proximal stomach
  • Contraindicated in any GI perforation- Esophageal or intestinal and Tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • There are three indentations in the esophagus :
  • 1st indentation- at the level of the Aortic Arch
  • 2nd indentation- at the level of Bronchus
  • 3rd indentation- at the level of the Left Atrium.

Barium meal

Tests the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum (the first part of the small intestine)

Barium follow through

  • Identify issues in the small intestine by tracking the passage of barium after ingestion.
  • After drinking a barium liquid, there is a 10-15 minute wait before X-rays are taken every 30 minutes until the barium reaches the large intestine.

Barium enema

  • Barium is given Transrectally.
  • Double-contrast (Barium + Air)
    • Positive contrast - Barium (white)
    • Negative contrast - Air (black)
  • Tests the pathologies of the large intestine- rectum, sigmoid colon and ascending, transverse and descending colon.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent dysphagia to solids but not liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiological findings?
questions.explanation:
A Rings

B Rings

C Rings
  • Muscular rings formed due to hypertrophy of smooth muscle in the distal esophagus.
  • Covered in squamous epithelium.
  • Transient and result from active muscle contraction.
  • Asymptomatic and incidentally noted during esophagography.
  • Lower esophageal rings - fixed, mucosal rings located at the squamocolumnar junction.
  • Commonly found just above a hiatal hernia.
  • Symptomatic B rings - Schatzki Rings (diameter <13 mm) may cause dysphagia, especially when food passes through the narrowed area.
  • Located distal to the squamocolumnar junction.
  • Covered by squamous epithelium.
  • Least common and asymptomatic.
  • Represent diaphragmatic indentation of the esophagus

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia. A barium swallow study is performed as part of the diagnostic workup. Which of the following radiographic findings is most characteristic of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) as shown in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Bird-beak appearance of the distal esophagus

options.label: B
options.text: Corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus

options.label: C
options.text: Smooth, tapered narrowing of the mid-esophagus

options.label: D
options.text: Saccular outpouchings along the entire length of the esophagus

questions.correct_answer: B. Corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Radiographic Findings

Description

Fluoroscopy (Barium Swallow)
  • "Corkscrew esophagus" or "rosary bead esophagus"
  • Non-peristaltic contractions pushing contrast in two directions
  • Normal appearance possible
  • 60% show abnormalities
  • <5% show "corkscrew esophagus"
  • Non-peristaltic contractions may be the only feature in some cases

CT
  • Circumferential wall thickening of the distal 5 cm of the esophagus
  • Seen in 20% of patients
  • Wall thickening ranges from 5 to 15 mm

 
  • Simultaneous contractions in the distal esophagus
  • Normal peristalsis interrupted by non-propulsive contractions
  • Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Not strictly a radiographic modality, but included for completeness

Esophageal Motility Disorder

LES Resting Pressure

LES Relaxation

Peristalsis

Contraction Amplitude

Normal

10-45 mmHg

Complete relaxation occur i.e ≤8 mmHg)

Coordinated peristalsis throughout

Normal amplitude is <180 mmHg

Achalasia

Elevated (>45 mmHg)

Incomplete relaxation (>8 mmHg)

Absent in the esophageal body

N/A

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Normal (≤45 mmHg)

Normal (≤8 mmHg)

Uncoordinated in >20% of swallows

Often high (>180 mmHg) in distal esophagus

Nutcracker Esophagus (Jackhammer Esophagus)

Normal (≤45 mmHg)

Normal (≤8 mmHg)

Normal

Very high (>220 mmHg)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with progressive dysphagia, initially for solids and later for liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, and two different radiographic findings are shown below. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between these images?

options.label: A
options.text: Image 1 shows achalasia cardia with a "bird beak" sign, while Image 2 shows carcinoma esophagus with irregular narrowing

options.label: B
options.text: Image 1 shows carcinoma esophagus with smooth narrowing, while Image 2 shows achalasia cardia

options.label: D
options.text: Both images show carcinoma esophagus affecting different parts of the esophagus

questions.correct_answer: A. Image 1 shows achalasia cardia with a "bird beak" sign, while Image 2 shows carcinoma esophagus with irregular narrowing
questions.explanation:
Feature

Achalasia Cardia (Image 1) (Option C)

Carcinoma Esophagus (Image 2) (Option D)

Esophageal Appearance

Massively dilated esophagus

Irregular narrowing of esophagus

Distal Esophagus (Option B)

Narrow lower end ("bird beak" sign)

Malignant stricture

Location

Affects lower esophageal sphincter

Mid-esophagus in this case

Contour

Smooth tapering at distal end

Irregular, abrupt narrowing

Additional Features

Proximal esophagus is dilated

May show shouldering or "apple core" appearance (not visible in this image)


Fig. Apple core appearance

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. A barium swallow examination is performed which is given below. Which of the following radiological findings is most consistent with the presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: An outpouching arising from the anterior wall of the proximal esophagus

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple small diverticula along the length of the esophagus

options.label: C
options.text: A diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx

options.label: D
options.text: A smooth narrowing of the distal esophagus

questions.correct_answer: C. A diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Key Findings

Barium Swallow (Fluoroscopy)
  • Diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx
  • Located near the pharyngoesophageal junction
  • Best identified during swallowing
  • Best seen on lateral view
  • Typically noted at the C5-6 level
  • May be transient (referred to as a "pharyngeal pouch")

Additional Findings
  • ~90% of patients also show a hiatal hernia and gastro-esophageal reflux
  • The distended sac may compress the cervical esophagus

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray is performed, showing free air in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following signs represents free air outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments?
questions.explanation:
Sign

Description

Decubitus abdomen sign

Free air between the abdominal wall and the liver on left lateral decubitus view

Ligament sign (Falciform ligament sign) (Option A)

Visualization of the falciform ligament due to free air on both sides

Inverted V sign

Air surrounding the lateral umbilical ligaments

Telltale sign (Triangle sign) (Option C)

Triangular accumulation of air between bowel loops

Doge cap sign (Option D)

Air in Morrison's/hepatorenal pouch

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and distension. An upright chest X-ray is performed, showing the following finding: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this radiographic finding?
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Key Findings of Pneumoperitoneum

Upright Chest X-ray
  • Subdiaphragmatic free gas
  • Continuous diaphragm sign

Supine Abdominal X-ray
  • Rigler's sign (gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity)
  • Cupola sign (air beneath the dome of diaphragm)
  • Football sign (oval-shaped collection of air in the upper abdomen)
  • Triangular air collection in Morrison's pouch

CT Scan
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Air outlining intra-abdominal organs
  • Air trapped between bowel loops

Ultrasound
  • Enhanced peritoneal stripe sign
  • Shifting phenomenon (movement of air with patient positioning)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and a rigid abdomen. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. An erect chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following radiological signs is NOT expected in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Free gas under the right hemidiaphragm

Given the high association with VACTERL anomalies, the medical team decides to conduct a series of radiographic studies to assess for potential associated conditions. Which of the following is a key imaging modality in the evaluation of a neonate with imperforate anus?
